awd_titl_txt: Underrepresented Engineering Students: Travel/Training Grant to Attend the International Microwave Symposium
awd_abstract_narration:
U.S. continued competitiveness in the global economy of the 21st century relies on maintaining a well-trained science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) workforce. The last two decades have focused on the U.S. lag in terms of the per capita graduates in STEM-related disciplines compared to an increasing number of European and Asian countries. A more pressing need and new for the first time in U.S. history is that the emerging majority of K-12 U.S. students are first-generation and from minority groups, who are significantly under-represented in engineering and other STEM -elated fields. The participation of underrepresented groups of women and minorities in Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) is far below their percentage representation of the population as a whole. This reality points to both systemic problems within the discipline in terms of attracting students to the field and suffers from the on-going discussions about achievement gaps in the K-12 education. The identification of appropriate role models and mentors within ECE in particular is deemed necessary to increase the efficiency of participants staying with the profession. The objectives of Project Connect are to directly address the aforementioned problems by exposing underrepresented students to exciting opportunities and potential mentors within the IEEE International Microwave Symposium (IMS) community related to broad technology areas such as electronics and communications.  These objectives will be met through the IMS 2018 and 2019 programming effort of Project Connect, which brings underrepresented university students to the symposium to engage with the university and industry professionals for exposure, guidance, and development in technical areas ranging from research and development, to applications and near-term industrial initiatives. The three primary objectives for the IMS Connect Program are to provide the following:(1)education about the rf/microwave industry,(2)awareness on career opportunities and expectations, and (3)access to and guidance from role models and potential mentors who are active in the field as educators, practitioners, researchers, and industry leaders. 

The support being requested from the National Science Foundation is for travel stipends for the student participants in IMS Connect for 2018 (Philadelphia, PA) and 2019 (Boston, MA). IMS is the largest conference in the world for RF/microwave engineers. Students who are selected to participate in IMS Connect will attend the conference for four days, in which they will participate in several professional development activities, learn about student activities for aspiring microwave engineers, and meet and network with  other engineering students, professionals, and leaders in the field. Selected student participants will also learn about microwave industries and local cultures in the conference location region.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Undergraduate electrical engineering student enrollment has been declining for many years and struggles with student attrition associated with academic struggle and lack of career transparency. Underrepresented minority and women engineering student success are affected at even higher rates, particularly for first generation students for additional reasons. Three attributes are linked to successful production of an engineer and launching of a career: (1) feeling a sense of belonging in the community, (2) having engineering identify formation and (3) having career identity formation. Belonging is associated with feeling welcome and accepted by peers and systems; identity is linked to receiving positive feedback from well-respected persons in the community system one is trying to join. Having limited experiences and limited support networks in engineering can make it more difficult to succeed.

Project Connect (PC) was developed to support career identity formation and offer community building and access to enhance a sense of belonging and engineering identity, respectively. The approach extends access to the engineering community beyond academic faculty though professional society activities. PC is designed to engage and connect URM undergraduate and first year graduate students to practicing engineers in the RF/microwave community through the IEEE Microwave Theory and Technology (MTT) Society and its flagship conference, IEEE International Microwave Symposium (IMS). MTT is a professional technical society that supports the RF/microwave industry field and its ecosystem by offering opportunities for interactions, engagement, and networking at conferences and other professional activities.

PC is co-located within the IMS, which serves as its host and as an immersive environment for students to learn about the field, meet practicing engineers, and observe how the RF/microwave field eco-system operates from a top view perspective.

During the week, students develop communication skills, meet liked minded peers, perform team building exercises, learn to network, learn about career paths and career options, and attend the conference. At the end of the week, the student teams process their experiences and present their favorites in a short ?Through Our Eyes? video. Afterwards, undergraduates determine if an RF/microwaves career is for them.  Interested ones leave knowing what courses to take and why; they also have access to practicing professionals to ask more questions about job responsibilities, options, and opportunities. Those in graduate school become more focused and clearer; some masters students even decide to pursue doctoral degrees.

Broader Impact

From 2014 to 2022, Project Connect engaged over 150 students from 45 universities. Seventy of those students from 29 universities were part of this grant period. Evaluation feedback during this grant period confirms that we have successfully achieved our goals to increase the participants knowledge related to the RF/microwave industry, to increase participants? awareness related to RF/microwave industry, and to increase the participants interest in pursuing a career in the RF/microwave industry.

The ethnic and gender demographics of the student participants is notable -- at least 55% female participants and 77% students of color. Even more outstanding is the fact that PC students pursue graduate degrees at 3- to 4-times the national average in the United States. Of the 49 students in the 2014-2020 cohorts who received their BS degrees at least 1 year after participating in Project Connect, 49% have completed a master?s program and 12% are in or have completed a Ph.D. program. Moreover, the current professional positions of the 2014 ? 2022 cohorts are predominantly in the RF/microwave/wireless field and graduate school.

 


Last Modified: 06/21/2023
Modified by: Rhonda R Franklin
